title: Jeremiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 6:1, from which direction does the evil and great destruction come?
questions.correctAnswer: North
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:1 states that evil appears out of the north, bringing great destruction.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah describe the daughter of Zion in Jeremiah 6:2?
questions.correctAnswer: A comely and delicate woman
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 6:2, the daughter of Zion is likened to a comely and delicate woman.

questions.question: What are the shepherds doing in Jeremiah 6:3?
options: Feeding their flocks and pitching tents around her
questions.correctAnswer: Feeding their flocks and pitching tents around her
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:3 says the shepherds with their flocks shall come unto her, pitch their tents around her, and feed every one in his place.

questions.question: What command does Jeremiah give in Jeremiah 6:4?
options: Prepare ye war against her; arise, and let us go up at noon
Build houses and dwell in peace
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare ye war against her; arise, and let us go up at noon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:4 commands to prepare war and arise to go up at noon against the city.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 6:5, when does Jeremiah say to arise and destroy her palaces?
questions.correctAnswer: By night
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:5 instructs to arise and go by night to destroy her palaces.

questions.question: What does the LORD of hosts command to do against Jerusalem in Jeremiah 6:6?
options: Hew down trees and cast up a mound
questions.correctAnswer: Hew down trees and cast up a mound
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:6 says the LORD commands to hew down trees and cast a mount against Jerusalem because it is a city full of oppression.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Jeremiah 6:7: 'As a fountain casteth out her waters, so she casteth out her ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: wickedness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:7 compares Jerusalem casting out her wickedness like a fountain casting out water.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 6:8 warns Jerusalem to be instructed, lest the LORD's soul depart from her.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:8 warns Jerusalem to be instructed or God’s soul will depart from her.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah say about the people's ears in Jeremiah 6:10?
options: Their ear is uncircumcised and they cannot hear
Their ear is attentive and hears well
Their ear is closed but they listen
questions.correctAnswer: Their ear is uncircumcised and they cannot hear
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:10 states their ear is uncircumcised and they cannot hearken to the warning.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 6:11 expresses that the LORD’s fury will be poured out on young men and children abroad.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:11 says the LORD’s fury will be poured out on children abroad and assemblies of young men.

questions.question: What is said about the prophets and priests in Jeremiah 6:13?
questions.correctAnswer: They all deal falsely
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:13 states that from the prophet even to the priest, every one deals falsely.

questions.question: What do they say in Jeremiah 6:14 when healing the hurt of the daughter of my people?
options: Peace, peace, when there is no peace
Joy, joy, for all is well
questions.correctAnswer: Peace, peace, when there is no peace
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:14 says they heal the hurt slightly, saying peace, peace, when there is no peace.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 6:16, what will those who walk in the old paths find?
questions.correctAnswer: Rest for their souls
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:16 says that walking in the old paths will bring rest for souls.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 6:17 says the people hearkened to the sound of the trumpet as instructed by the watchmen.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:17 states that the watchmen said to hearken to the trumpet, but the people said, 'We will not hearken.'

questions.question: What is the reason given in Jeremiah 6:19 for the evil God will bring upon the people?
options: Because they have not hearkened to His words nor to His law
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have not hearkened to His words nor to His law
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:19 explains evil will come because they rejected God's words and law.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear about impending trials. Based on Jeremiah 6, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's sovereign control?
options: God has promised to bring a great nation against Jerusalem as a judgment.
God encourages His people to prepare for war on their own strength.
God rejects all sacrifices and offerings as meaningless.
God has set a tower and fortress to know and try the way of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God has set a tower and fortress to know and try the way of His people.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:27 says God has set Jerusalem as a tower and fortress to know and try the way of His people, showing His sovereign control over the trials. This teaches believers to trust God even in hard times (6:1-6, 6:22-23).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 6 teach us about the importance of obedience to God's Word when facing spiritual blindness or hardness of heart?
options: People's ears are uncircumcised and they cannot listen to God's warnings.
God's words are always accepted gladly by the people.
The people follow the old paths faithfully.
Prophets and priests lead the people in truth and righteousness.
questions.correctAnswer: People's ears are uncircumcised and they cannot listen to God's warnings.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:10 explains that the people have uncircumcised ears and do not hear God's warnings, rejecting His word. This underlines the need for humility and obedience to God's teaching (6:10, 6:16-17).

questions.question: In the context of family life and parenting, what warning does Jeremiah 6 give about the consequences of rejecting God's law?
options: Fathers and sons will fall together over the stumblingblocks laid by God.
God promises peace and prosperity for families who reject His ways.
Only the young men will face judgment, not the older generation.
Families will be united in joy because of God's mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: Fathers and sons will fall together over the stumblingblocks laid by God.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:21 warns that both fathers and sons will fall together because of the stumblingblocks God will lay before the people, illustrating consequences for families rejecting His law (6:11-12, 6:21).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their efforts to bring peace seem ineffective. Based on Jeremiah 6, what biblical insight can you offer about false peace?
options: False peace is proclaimed while there is actually no peace, leading to judgment.
Peace will come quickly to those who deny their sin.
God accepts all sacrifices as tokens of peace.
Peace is guaranteed when people ignore God's warnings.
questions.correctAnswer: False peace is proclaimed while there is actually no peace, leading to judgment.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:14 states that they say 'Peace, peace,' when there is no peace, indicating that false assurance leads to ruin. This teaches the importance of genuine repentance and truth (6:14-15, 6:19).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 6 encourage believers to find spiritual rest and guidance in life?
options: By standing in the ways and asking for the old paths, then walking in them.
By creating new paths that suit their own understanding.
By relying on human wisdom rather than God's word.
By ignoring the warnings and continuing in their own ways.
questions.correctAnswer: By standing in the ways and asking for the old paths, then walking in them.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:16 encourages believers to seek the old paths where the good way is found, promising rest for souls to those who obey. This highlights the value of obedience and humility (6:16-17, 6:10).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 6 teaches that God's anger will be poured out only on the young men, sparing the families.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:11 explains God's fury will be poured out on children abroad and the assembly of young men together, and verse 12 adds that houses, fields, and wives will be turned over to others, meaning families are included in judgment.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 6 teach about integrity and honesty in the leaders of God's people?
options: From prophets to priests, everyone deals falsely and is given to covetousness.
Leaders faithfully uphold justice and truth before God.
Only a few leaders are corrupt, while most are honest.
Leaders prioritize God's law above personal gain.
questions.correctAnswer: From prophets to priests, everyone deals falsely and is given to covetousness.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:13 states that from the least to the greatest, including prophets and priests, everyone is covetous and deals falsely, warning believers to pursue honesty and integrity (6:13, 6:28).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 6 instruct believers to respond when God warns them through His watchmen?
options: To hearken to the sound of the trumpet and obey God's warnings.
To reject the warnings and continue in their own ways.
To rely on their own strength instead of listening.
To delay repentance until the very last moment.
questions.correctAnswer: To hearken to the sound of the trumpet and obey God's warnings.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:17 says watchmen are set to warn the people to listen to the trumpet sound, but they refused. The passage encourages believers to respond with obedience and repentance (6:16-17, 6:19).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to offer sacrifices without true repentance. What does Jeremiah 6 say about such offerings?
options: Burnt offerings and sacrifices are not acceptable to God without obedience.
God delights in all sacrifices regardless of the heart.
Sacrifices alone can atone for sin without lifestyle change.
Offering incense from Sheba pleases the Lord.
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt offerings and sacrifices are not acceptable to God without obedience.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:20 states that burnt offerings and sacrifices are not acceptable to God when His law is rejected, emphasizing the need for true obedience over ritual (6:19-20).

questions.question: What practical advice does Jeremiah 6 give to those experiencing anguish and fear due to coming judgment?
options: Do not go into the field or walk by the way because of the sword and fear.
Ignore the fear and continue daily activities as usual.
Prepare palaces and fortresses to resist the enemy.
Rely on human alliances for protection.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not go into the field or walk by the way because of the sword and fear.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:25 advises not to go into the field or walk by the way due to the enemy's sword and widespread fear, teaching prudence and recognizing when to be cautious in trials (6:24-26).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 6 describes the people of Jerusalem as a comely and delicate woman, signifying their innocence and protection.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:2 compares the daughter of Zion to a comely and delicate woman, symbolizing the beauty and vulnerability of Jerusalem, which calls for care and faithful protection.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 6 illustrate God's grief over the people's persistent wickedness and violence?
options: God's presence is continually grieved by their wounds and violence like a fountain casting out waters.
God rejoices over their sacrifices despite their actions.
The people’s wickedness is hidden and causes no grief to God.
God is indifferent to their violence because of their numbers.
questions.correctAnswer: God's presence is continually grieved by their wounds and violence like a fountain casting out waters.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:7 compares the people's wickedness to a fountain casting out its waters, causing continual grief and wounds before God, showing His sorrow over their sin (6:7, 6:14-15).

questions.question: A believer struggles with perseverance through trials. Based on Jeremiah 6, what encouragement can you give about God's justice and discipline?
options: God’s discipline involves both judgment and a call to repentance for restoration.
God will ignore the wicked indefinitely.
Trials mean God has abandoned His people.
Only the wicked will suffer without hope for mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s discipline involves both judgment and a call to repentance for restoration.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6 presents God’s judgment as a consequence of sin but also includes calls to return to the good paths (6:16) and hear the trumpet’s sound (6:17), encouraging perseverance with repentance and hope.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 6 compares the people to ________ silver because the LORD has rejected them.
questions.correctAnswer: reprobate
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:30 calls the people 'reprobate silver' because the LORD has rejected them, illustrating their moral corruption and God's disapproval.

questions.question: How can believers apply Jeremiah 6's teaching about stewardship and work ethic amid corruption and falsehood?
options: By acting with honesty and integrity even when others are corrupt.
By adopting the same falsehoods to survive.
By neglecting their work since judgment is coming.
By seeking wealth at any cost.
questions.correctAnswer: By acting with honesty and integrity even when others are corrupt.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:13-14 shows widespread falsehood and corruption, but believers are called to live differently, maintaining integrity and faithfulness in their work and stewardship.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 6:1, which locations are mentioned as places to signal the coming evil from the north?
questions.correctAnswer: Tekoa and Bethhaccerem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:1 instructs the children of Benjamin to blow the trumpet in Tekoa and set up a sign of fire in Bethhaccerem to warn of the evil coming from the north.

questions.question: Jeremiah 6:2 likens the daughter of Zion to which of the following?
questions.correctAnswer: A comely and delicate woman
questions.explanation: Verse 2 uses the metaphor of a comely and delicate woman to describe the daughter of Zion, highlighting her fragility and beauty before the coming judgment.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 6:3, what role do the shepherds and their flocks play in relation to Zion?
options: They shall come unto her and pitch tents round about
They shall build walls around her
questions.correctAnswer: They shall come unto her and pitch tents round about
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:3 describes shepherds coming with their flocks to Zion, pitching tents around her and feeding in their places, indicating encirclement possibly for siege.

questions.question: What command is given in Jeremiah 6:4 concerning the timing of the war preparations?
options: Arise, and let us go up at noon
questions.correctAnswer: Arise, and let us go up at noon
questions.explanation: Verse 4 commands to prepare for war and go up at noon, emphasizing urgency as the day fades and shadows lengthen.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 6:6, what specific instructions does the LORD give regarding Jerusalem's defense?
options: Hew down trees and cast a mount against Jerusalem
Build higher walls and dig moats
Hide in the caves and wait
questions.correctAnswer: Hew down trees and cast a mount against Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:6 records God's command to hew down trees and build a mound against Jerusalem, indicating a siege and imminent destruction.

questions.question: The phrase 'as a fountain casteth out her waters' in Jeremiah 6:7 is a metaphor for what?
options: The continuous outpouring of wickedness from Jerusalem
A healing spring in the city
questions.correctAnswer: The continuous outpouring of wickedness from Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Verse 7 uses this metaphor to describe how Jerusalem incessantly pours out wickedness, violence, and spoil, causing continual grief before God.

questions.question: Jeremiah 6:10 compares the people's ears to which of the following, indicating their refusal to listen?
questions.correctAnswer: Uncircumcised ears
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states their ears are uncircumcised, a Hebrew idiom meaning they are stubborn and unwilling to hear God's warnings.

questions.question: Jeremiah expresses his frustration in Jeremiah 6:11 by stating he is full of what?
questions.correctAnswer: The fury of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 11 clearly states Jeremiah is full of the LORD's fury and weary of holding it in, signifying impending divine judgment.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 6:13, what sin is attributed to everyone from the least to the greatest, including prophets and priests?
questions.correctAnswer: Covetousness and false dealing
questions.explanation: Verse 13 indicts all levels of society, including religious leaders, for greed and deceitful behavior.

questions.question: The phrase 'Peace, peace; when there is no peace' in Jeremiah 6:14 is an example of which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:14 uses irony to highlight false assurances of peace when, in reality, there is none.

questions.question: Jeremiah 6:16 calls the people to 'ask for the old paths' and 'walk therein' to find what?
questions.correctAnswer: Rest for your souls
questions.explanation: Verse 16 promises that walking in the old, good paths leads to rest for the soul, emphasizing the value of returning to God's ways.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 6:17, the watchmen's warnings were heeded by the people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:17 states that the watchmen were set to alert the people, but they refused to listen to the trumpet's sound.

questions.question: Jeremiah 6:19 attributes the evil to be brought upon the people as the fruit of what?
questions.correctAnswer: Their thoughts
questions.explanation: Verse 19 explains that the evil is the consequence of the people's own thoughts because they rejected God's words and law.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 6:22-23, the invading people from the north are described using which of the following characteristics?
options: Cruel, merciless, roaring like the sea
Gentle, kind, quiet as a lamb
questions.correctAnswer: Cruel, merciless, roaring like the sea
questions.explanation: Verses 22-23 describe the northern invaders as cruel and merciless, with a voice roaring like the sea, prepared for war.

questions.question: Jeremiah 6:26 uses the imagery of mourning for an only son to describe what action for the daughter of God's people?
options: Girding with sackcloth and wallowing in ashes
questions.correctAnswer: Girding with sackcloth and wallowing in ashes
questions.explanation: Verse 26 commands mourning rituals like wearing sackcloth and ashes, expressing deep grief as for a lost only son.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 6, what signifies the impending great destruction coming from the north?
options: Blowing the trumpet in Tekoa and setting up a sign of fire in Bethhaccerem
questions.correctAnswer: Blowing the trumpet in Tekoa and setting up a sign of fire in Bethhaccerem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:1 calls for the children of Benjamin to blow the trumpet in Tekoa and set up a sign of fire in Bethhaccerem because evil and great destruction are coming from the north. This signals a prophetic warning similar to other biblical warnings of judgment such as in Ezekiel 33:3-6 and Joel 2:1.

questions.question: Jeremiah likens the daughter of Zion to which figure, highlighting her vulnerability?
questions.correctAnswer: A comely and delicate woman
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 6:2, Zion is likened to a comely and delicate woman, emphasizing her beauty and fragility, which contrasts with the coming judgment. This imagery recalls the bride of Israel in Isaiah 62:5 and the vulnerable yet beloved people of God in Revelation 21:2.

questions.question: What is the LORD’s instruction in Jeremiah 6:6 regarding Jerusalem’s defense?
options: Hew down trees and cast up a mound against Jerusalem
Build high walls and prepare weapons
Gather priests to pray for protection
questions.correctAnswer: Hew down trees and cast up a mound against Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:6 records God’s command to hew down trees and cast up a mound against Jerusalem, symbolizing preparation for siege and judgment. This reflects God's impending judgment upon a city that has become oppressive, paralleling themes in 2 Kings 19:32 and Ezekiel 4:1-3.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 6, what is continually before the LORD due to Jerusalem's sin?
questions.correctAnswer: Grief and wounds
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:7 states that before the LORD are continually grief and wounds because Jerusalem casts out wickedness like a fountain. This persistent sorrow reflects God's righteous judgment as seen also in Psalm 78:40 and Isaiah 1:5.

questions.question: What reason does Jeremiah 6:10 give for the people's failure to heed God's warnings?
options: Their ear is uncircumcised and they cannot hearken
They are too busy with offerings
They trust in their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Their ear is uncircumcised and they cannot hearken
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:10 describes the people's inability to hear God's warnings because their ears are 'uncircumcised,' a metaphor for spiritual insensitivity. This aligns with other biblical teaching on hardened hearts, such as in Ezekiel 36:26 and Hebrews 3:8.

questions.question: What emotion fills Jeremiah because of the LORD's impending judgment as described in Jeremiah 6:11?
options: Fury and weariness with holding it in
questions.correctAnswer: Fury and weariness with holding it in
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:11 reveals Jeremiah is full of the LORD’s fury and weary of holding it back, indicating the prophet’s deep burden over coming judgment. This experience is similar to the feelings of prophets like Ezekiel (Ezekiel 2:6) and Paul (Romans 9:2-3) who were distressed over the people's sin.

questions.question: Who are described as being given over to covetousness and false dealings in Jeremiah 6:13?
options: From the least to the greatest, including prophets and priests
questions.correctAnswer: From the least to the greatest, including prophets and priests
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:13 states that from the least to the greatest, including prophets and priests, everyone is given to covetousness and deceit. This universal corruption contrasts with God’s call for holiness found in 1 Peter 1:15-16 and Ezekiel 22:26.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 6:14, what false message do the leaders give to the people, and why is it incorrect?
options: "Peace, peace," when there is no peace
questions.correctAnswer: "Peace, peace," when there is no peace
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:14 condemns leaders who say "Peace, peace" when there is no peace, a false assurance that misleads the people. This deception is similar to warnings in Ezekiel 13:10 and 2 Thessalonians 2:11 about false prophets and deceptive peace.

questions.question: What invitation does the LORD extend in Jeremiah 6:16 regarding the "old paths"?
options: To stand in the ways, ask for the old paths, and find rest for their souls
To build new altars and follow new laws
To flee to distant lands for safety
To offer sacrifices to appease God
questions.correctAnswer: To stand in the ways, ask for the old paths, and find rest for their souls
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:16 invites the people to seek the old paths, the good way of God, promising rest for their souls. This call to repentance echoes Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 11:28-30 and the wisdom of Proverbs 3:17.

questions.question: Despite God’s warning to listen to the watchmen and the sound of the trumpet, how do the people respond in Jeremiah 6:17?
questions.correctAnswer: They refuse to hearken
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:17 states that the people refuse to listen to the watchmen’s trumpet warnings, demonstrating their persistent rebellion. This hardened response is similar to Israel’s rejection of God’s prophets in 1 Kings 19:10 and Hebrews 3:12.

questions.question: What reason does Jeremiah 6:20 give for God’s rejection of the people’s incense and sacrifices?
options: Because they have not hearkened to His words and law but have rejected them
Because the offerings were not made in the temple
Because the sacrifices were of unclean animals
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have not hearkened to His words and law but have rejected them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:20 explains that the people’s incense and sacrifices are not acceptable because they have not obeyed God’s law and words but have rejected them. This principle is echoed in Isaiah 1:11-17 and Hosea 6:6 where God desires obedience over ritual.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 6:22-23, what describes the invading people coming from the north?
options: A great nation, cruel, merciless, with voices like the roaring sea
A nation that will be defeated quickly
questions.correctAnswer: A great nation, cruel, merciless, with voices like the roaring sea
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:22-23 describes a great and cruel nation from the north, merciless and like the roaring sea, arrayed for war against Zion. This imagery matches prophetic descriptions of Assyria and Babylon in Isaiah 10:5-7 and Nahum 1:3.

questions.question: What is the emotional reaction of the people upon hearing of the approaching enemy in Jeremiah 6:24?
options: Their hands grow feeble and anguish takes hold like a woman in labor
questions.correctAnswer: Their hands grow feeble and anguish takes hold like a woman in labor
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:24 depicts the people’s fearful response as their hands grow weak and anguish grips them like a woman in childbirth. This vivid metaphor indicates intense distress similar to Isaiah 13:8 and Revelation 12:2.

questions.question: What action does Jeremiah 6:26 call the daughter of God’s people to perform in response to the coming judgment?
options: Gird herself with sackcloth and mourn bitterly as for an only son
Build new altars and offer sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Gird herself with sackcloth and mourn bitterly as for an only son
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:26 calls for mourning in sackcloth and ashes, lamenting bitterly as for an only son lost, signifying deep repentance and sorrow. This is consistent with biblical expressions of grief in 2 Samuel 1:11-12 and Lamentations 2:10.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 6:30 say about those rejected by the LORD, and what does this signify?
options: They shall be called reprobate silver, signifying their rejection and worthlessness
They shall be exalted above others
They shall receive mercy despite their sins
They shall return to the land in peace
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be called reprobate silver, signifying their rejection and worthlessness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 6:30 states the LORD will call the people 'reprobate silver,' symbolizing their rejection and loss of value due to sin. This metaphor is echoed in Malachi 1:2-3 and 1 Corinthians 3:13-15 concerning judgment and worthiness.
